1. Gaussian Distribution (Normal Distribution):
	- The most commonly used distribution in statistics and machine learning.
	- Characterized by a bell-shaped curve with a symmetric and continuous probability density function.
	- Parameters: mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ).
	- Widely applicable for modeling continuous variables.
		![](https://www.allaboutcircuits.com/uploads/articles/the-normal-distribution-understanding-probabilities-in-measured-data-rk-aac-image1.jpg)
		$$\mu = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n x_i}{n}$$
		$$\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \mu)^2}{n}}$$
		$$\sigma^2 = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \mu)^2}{n}$$
	
2. Bernoulli Distribution:
	- Represents a binary outcome (0 or 1) with a single trial.
	- Parameter: probability of success (p).
	- Useful for modeling binary variables, such as coin flips or binary classification problems.
		![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1400/format:webp/1*thPp6LSSLhfpR1IAMoOGEg.png)
		- Mean
		$$m = p$$ where P is the success rate.
		- Variance
		$$\sigma^2 = p(1-p)$$
3. Binomial Distribution:

	- Generalization of the Bernoulli distribution to multiple independent trials.
	- Represents the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials.
	- Parameters: number of trials (n) and probability of success (p).
	- Useful for modeling the count of binary outcomes, such as the number of heads in multiple coin flips.
	 ![](https://blogs.sas.com/content/iml/files/2021/11/BinomNormal1.png)
	- Mean = $$m = n p$$
	- Variance = $$\sigma^2 = np(1-p)$$
4. Poisson Distribution:
	- Models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time or space.
	- Often used for count data when the events occur at a constant rate.
	- Parameter: average rate of events (λ).
	- Commonly used in scenarios like customer arrivals, website visits, or machine failures.
		![](data:image/png;base64,)
		- Mean = $$\mu = \lambda$$
		- Variance = $$\sigma^2 = \lambda$$
		- Standard Deviation = $$\sigma = \sqrt{\lambda}$$

5. Exponential Distribution:

	- Describes the time between events in a Poisson process.
	- Parameter: rate parameter (λ), which represents the average number of events per unit of time.
	- Useful for modeling time-to-failure or time-to-event data.
		![](data:image/png;base64,)
		- Mean = $$\mu = \frac{1}{\lambda}$$
		- Variance = $$\sigma^2 = \frac{1}{\lambda^2}$$
6. Uniform Distribution:

	- Represents a constant probability over a defined interval.
	- All values in the interval have equal likelihood.
	- Parameters: minimum value (a) and maximum value (b).
	- Useful for modeling scenarios where all outcomes are equally likely, such as random number generation.
		![](https://www.alphacodingskills.com/numpy/img/uniform-distribution-1.png)
		- Mean = $$\mu = \frac{a+b}{2}$$
		- Variance = $$\sigma^2 = \frac{(b-a)^2}{12}$$
7. Gamma Distribution:
	- Generalization of the exponential distribution.
	- Models the time until a specified number of events occur in a Poisson process.
	- Parameters: shape parameter (k) and rate parameter (θ).
		![](data:image/png;base64,)
		- Mean = $$\mu = \frac{k}{\theta}$$
		- Variance = $$\sigma^2 = k\theta^2$$

The populations parameters are referred to the Mean and Standard Deviation.
